headline: Tech Was Supposed to Get Political. It’s Hanging Back in This Election.
abstract: While voters get ready for California’s primary on June 5, Silicon Valley’s tech community — which had been politically outspoken — has tried to stay largely under the radar.

headline: Net Neutrality Has Officially Been Repealed. Here’s How That Could Affect You.
abstract: Net Neutrality rules that required internet service providers to offer equal access to all web content are no longer in effect as of Monday.

headline: Video Shows Israeli Forces Shooting a Palestinian, Then Rejoicing
abstract: The military said the event apparently took place a few months ago, but the footage emerged as Palestinians mourned the fresh deaths of 30 protesters.

headline: Israelis Reflect on Gaza: ‘I Hope at Least That Each Bullet Was Justified’
abstract: A day after their soldiers killed 60 mostly unarmed Palestinians in Gaza, Israelis were defiant, defensive or blasé.

headline: Natalie Portman Backs Out of Israeli Award Ceremony
abstract: The latest celebrity to opt out of an event in Israel over disagreements with its government, Ms. Portman cited her distress over “recent events” in Israel.

headline: Netanyahu’s Reversal on Migrants Shows Influence of Hard-Line Allies
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu faced an outcry from his base over a deal with the United Nations to keep thousands of African migrants in Israel.

headline: Exiled in the U.S., a Lawyer Warns of ‘China’s Long Arm’
abstract: Teng Biao, a pre-eminent human rights attorney, is alarmed by Beijing’s success in spreading repressive policies by flexing its market power.

headline: Tibetan Advocate’s Prison Term in China Is Condemned
abstract: “We are gravely concerned about the sentencing of Mr. Tashi Wangchuk,” U.N. human rights experts said. Mr. Wangchuk was given five years in prison.

headline: Sturm Ruger Shareholders Adopt Measure Backed by Gun Safety Activists
abstract: The measure, which the gun maker’s board opposed, calls on the company to look into safer firearms and to explain how it keeps track of crimes committed with its products.

headline: A Place by a Lake or in the Woods: the Canada Letter
abstract: In Canada, there’s lots of land but not many people, which has made it possible for summer “cottages” to be a part of many Canadians’ lives. Rising prices, however, may threaten that.

headline: Migration Agency Picks a New Leader, and Sends Trump a Message
abstract: The International Organization for Migration will be led by António Vitorino, after Ken Isaacs, the American nominee, withdrew because of a lack of support.

headline: Tesla Model 3 Goes Upscale, and Base-Price Buyers Must Wait
abstract: Elon Musk, the electric-car company’s chief, said Tesla would lose money and die if it began selling the cheapest version of its mass-market car too soon.

headline: Consumer Bureau’s Chief Gives Big Raises, Even as He Criticizes Spending
abstract: Mick Mulvaney, who is trying to rein in the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, awarded large pay increases to two recent recruits.

headline: Banks Adopt Military-Style Tactics to Fight Cybercrime
abstract: Financial institutions are using military tools and techniques, like “fusion centers” and combat drills, to battle cybercrime.

headline: For All His Deals, Trump Has Never Faced an Adversary Like Kim Jong-un
abstract: How President Trump and Mr. Kim — both volatile, thin-skinned and eager never to show weakness — will interact with each other is the great mystery of the summit meeting.

headline: Tariff Impact Colors a Key House Race in Boeing Country
abstract: Democrats have their eye on flipping a congressional seat in a district near Seattle, in a state that has more at stake in a trade war than any other.

headline: And to Think That I Saw It in New York Harbor
abstract: A diver investigates the condition of floating docks and underwater structures and encounters adventure along the way.

headline: ISIS Spokesman Calls for Attacks on Arab Nations
abstract: For years, ISIS called for attacks abroad. In the latest speech by its spokesman, the group is focusing on enemies closer to home.

headline: Indonesia Church Bombings Carried Out by Family With Children in Tow
abstract: Officials said a couple in the city of Surabaya led four youths, ages 18 to 9, in setting off explosions that killed at least seven people and were claimed by ISIS.

headline: Understanding Ireland’s Vote on Whether to Keep Its Abortion Ban
abstract: Results of two exit polls released Friday night showed voters had favored repeal by a wide margin.

headline: 2 Dead in Münster, Germany, After Truck Driver Crashes Into Crowd
abstract: Two were killed and about 20 injured on Saturday after a vehicle crashed into a group of people in the heart of the old city, the police said. The driver, a German citizen, killed himself afterward.

headline: Ireland Votes to End Abortion Ban, in Rebuke to Catholic Conservatism
abstract: The referendum was the latest sign of a drift toward liberalism in a country that only recently installed a gay man as prime minister and allowed same-sex marriage.

headline: Promoting Europe’s Conservatives, U.S. Envoy Upsets Germans
abstract: Ambassador Richard Grenell flouted protocol, saying he wanted to “empower” leaders challenging “failed policies of the left.” Berlin asked him to clarify.

headline: Mosul’s Renowned Religious Complex Will Rise From the Rubble
abstract: The United Arab Emirates is donating $50 million to rebuild the Al Nuri Grand Mosque. It will be the largest cultural restoration project in Iraq.

headline: Behind a Roadside Hit in Malaysia, Israeli-Palestinian Intrigue
abstract: An engineer is the latest Hamas figure to be targeted abroad by Israel’s Mossad spy agency, officials say, as another conspiracy plays out in Kuala Lumpur.

headline: At the Heart of Indonesia Terror Attacks, a Well-Liked Family
abstract: Before sending his children to blow themselves up at Christian churches, Dita Oepriarto was a neighborhood favorite with a secret link to the Islamic State.

headline: Anniversary of Thai Coup Draws Uneasy Protest and Police Threats
abstract: Officials in Bangkok warned that demonstrators fighting for a return to civilian government had been identified through photographs and video footage, and that they could be prosecuted.

headline: Ruling on Airbus Subsidies Could Escalate Trade Tensions With Europe
abstract: The World Trade Organization found that Europe had improperly subsidized Airbus to the detriment of Boeing. The Trump administration said it could retaliate against imports of European products.

headline: As China Curbs Borrowing, Growth Shows Signs of Faltering
abstract: The country’s focus on reducing its debt has left small businesses facing a credit crunch, and the economy appears to be slowing.

headline: Free Power From Freeways? China Is Testing Roads Paved With Solar Panels
abstract: Western countries have been looking into putting solar panels on roads for years. The Chinese have done it, installing panels on a downhill section of a mountain road.

headline: Fire at South China Karaoke Bar Kills 18, and Suspect Is Arrested
abstract: A state news outlet reported that the person who set the blaze blocked the only entrance to the lounge, in a three-story building in Guangdong Province.

headline: For Faulting a Chinese Tonic, He Got 3 Months in Jail. Then Cheers.
abstract: A doctor who suggested that a popular, alcohol-based tonic was dangerous was held for nearly 100 days. He emerged as a public hero.

headline: U.N. and Red Cross Pull Out of Yemeni City, Fearing Assault by Arab Coalition
abstract: Diplomats say the United Arab Emirates plans to attack Hudaydah, a rebel-held port that is an entry point for humanitarian aid.

headline: China Is Set to Take a Hard Line on Trump’s Trade Demands
abstract: Beijing sees its economy as robust enough to defy U.S. tariff threats, potentially leaving Washington with no choice but to escalate or back down.

headline: Trump’s Charm and Threats May Not Be Working on China. Here’s Why.
abstract: President Trump threatened tariffs on $150 billion in goods, then tried conciliation. Beijing’s response either way: Rebuff the offers and avoid specific pledges.

headline: Australia Pledges Millions of Dollars in Bid to Rescue Great Barrier Reef
abstract: The government will set aside 500 million Australian dollars to help the global treasure after years of damage from warming waters caused by climate change.

headline: Mass Shooting in Australia Leaves a Tiny Community in Shock and Grief
abstract: The killing of a family of seven, apparently in a murder-suicide, was the worst incident of its kind in the country in more than 20 years.

headline: Cardinal George Pell’s Sexual Abuse Trials May Be Held in Secret
abstract: Prosecutors in Australia have applied for a “super injunction” that would keep all details — even the judge’s name — from being reported.

headline: Britain’s Wedding-Mad Tabloids Feel a Cold Royal Shoulder
abstract: The wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle may be the event of the year for the popular press, but only one reporter will be present for the ceremony.

headline: Poisoned Door Handle Hints at High-Level Plot to Kill Spy, U.K. Officials Say
abstract: An operation to smear a nerve agent on Sergei Skripal’s door handle was so risky, it is unlikely to have been tried without Kremlin approval, British officials investigating the case believe.

headline: Yulia Skripal Describes ‘Extremely Painful’ Recovery From Poisoning
abstract: The victim of a nerve agent attack gave her first videotaped statement, in an attempt to quell swirling speculation, especially from Russia.

headline: At Site of U.K. Poisoning, Doubts About Case Creep In
abstract: As British investigators remained silent about the poisoning of Sergei V. Skripal and his daughter, Russia flooded social media with alternative theories, leading some in Salisbury to raise questions.

headline: Suspects in Attack on Ex-Spy Are in Russia, U.K. Newspaper Reports
abstract: Investigators identified the suspects by scanning flight manifests for passengers entering and exiting Britain, The Daily Telegraph reported. The police would not confirm the report.

headline: As Trump Escalates Trade Fight, China Can Take the Hit
abstract: The trade measures President Trump is imposing will do little to hurt China’s growth, though they could add to Beijing’s problems down the road.

headline: Syrian Forces Aimed to Kill Journalists, U.S. Court Is Told
abstract: Evidence was presented in a wrongful-death suit against Syria’s government brought by the family of Marie Colvin, a war reporter who died in 2012.

headline: Influential Politician in India Is Accused of Driving Wife to Suicide
abstract: Shashi Tharoor, one of India’s suavest opposition politicians, was charged with cruelty to a woman and abetting suicide.

headline: Killer Dogs Take 14 Lives. Did Closing Slaughterhouses Play a Role?
abstract: Villagers whose children have been killed by wild dogs blame Hindu-right politicians for closing slaughterhouses, which they say has deprived dogs of food and made them violent.

headline: Avalanches. Frostbite. Double Amputation. Still, He Scaled Mt. Everest.
abstract: A Chinese mountain climber who lost his legs and tried many times to climb Mt. Everest reached the top on Monday.

headline: Indian Actress Stages a Topless #MeToo Protest
abstract: Sri Reddy, 28, took off her shirt outside a film commission in Hyderabad to draw attention to her accusations of sexual harassment by movie producers.

headline: Saudi Arabia Detains Activists Who Pushed to End Ban on Women Driving
abstract: At least five people connected to the campaign to end the longtime ban have been detained, despite the government’s promise to lift the ban next month.

headline: Tech Was Supposed to Get Political. It’s Hanging Back in This Election.
abstract: While voters get ready for California’s primary on June 5, Silicon Valley’s tech community — which had been politically outspoken — has tried to stay largely under the radar.

headline: Net Neutrality Has Officially Been Repealed. Here’s How That Could Affect You.
abstract: Net Neutrality rules that required internet service providers to offer equal access to all web content are no longer in effect as of Monday.

abstract: The military said the event apparently took place a few months ago, but the footage emerged as Palestinians mourned the fresh deaths of 30 protesters.

headline: Israelis Reflect on Gaza: ‘I Hope at Least That Each Bullet Was Justified’
abstract: A day after their soldiers killed 60 mostly unarmed Palestinians in Gaza, Israelis were defiant, defensive or blasé.

headline: Natalie Portman Backs Out of Israeli Award Ceremony
abstract: The latest celebrity to opt out of an event in Israel over disagreements with its government, Ms. Portman cited her distress over “recent events” in Israel.

headline: Netanyahu’s Reversal on Migrants Shows Influence of Hard-Line Allies
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu faced an outcry from his base over a deal with the United Nations to keep thousands of African migrants in Israel.

headline: Exiled in the U.S., a Lawyer Warns of ‘China’s Long Arm’
abstract: Teng Biao, a pre-eminent human rights attorney, is alarmed by Beijing’s success in spreading repressive policies by flexing its market power.

headline: Tibetan Advocate’s Prison Term in China Is Condemned
abstract: “We are gravely concerned about the sentencing of Mr. Tashi Wangchuk,” U.N. human rights experts said. Mr. Wangchuk was given five years in prison.

headline: Sturm Ruger Shareholders Adopt Measure Backed by Gun Safety Activists
abstract: The measure, which the gun maker’s board opposed, calls on the company to look into safer firearms and to explain how it keeps track of crimes committed with its products.

headline: A Place by a Lake or in the Woods: the Canada Letter
abstract: In Canada, there’s lots of land but not many people, which has made it possible for summer “cottages” to be a part of many Canadians’ lives. Rising prices, however, may threaten that.

headline: Poison Gas Attack Reported by Syrian Anti-Government Activists
abstract: Anti-government activists accused the Syrian government of attacking a rebel-held suburb of Damascus with poison gas, estimating that dozens were killed.

headline: Cinema Ban Lifts as ‘Black Panther’ Is Screened for Saudi Audience
abstract: A V.I.P. screening of the Hollywood blockbuster “Black Panther” in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, marked the end of a decades-old ban on movie theaters.

headline: China’s #MeToo: How a 20-Year-Old Rape Case Became a Rallying Cry
abstract: Before killing herself, Gao Yan accused her professor of assault. Her death may now force a belated reckoning in China’s male-dominated halls of power.

headline: Tour Bus Crashes in North Korea, Killing 36, Chinese Officials Say
abstract: The crash occurred at a time of intense diplomacy in the region, as a summit meeting between the leaders of North and South Korea approaches.

headline: Making History, Saudi Arabia Issues Driver’s Licenses to 10 Women
abstract: The kingdom had planned to lift its longstanding ban on women driving on June 24. It is unclear why it issued some licenses ahead of the schedule.

headline: Banker Finds He Has ‘Even More Enemies Than I Thought’
abstract: Accused of bribery, Ilmars Rimsevics, Latvia’s widely disliked central banker, seems headed for a fall, along with one of the nation’s largest banks.

headline: Missile Attack in Syria Reportedly Kills at Least 16, Raising Regional Tensions
abstract: Suspicions fell on Israel, which has bombed what are believed to be convoys transporting Iran’s weapons to its regional allies.

headline: E.U. Leader Warns of ‘Worst-Case Scenarios,’ Citing Trump
abstract: Donald Tusk, head of the European Council, warned leaders that there were deep divisions in the trans-Atlantic relationship as a trade war loomed.

headline: Allies at Cross-Purposes: Trump Puts Europe Into Damage-Control Mode
abstract: America’s allies met with Iran to try to preserve the nuclear deal, while criticizing the bloodshed surrounding the U.S. Embassy’s move to Jerusalem.

headline: Migration to Europe Is Slowing, but the Political Issue Is as Toxic as Ever
abstract: Under political pressure, Angela Merkel secured the help of the European Commission to call an unusual weekend meeting on how to manage migration.

headline: As Taboos Break Down, Iranians Party On
abstract: Laws governing personal behavior are being roundly ignored, particularly in the exploding business of providing Western-style weddings.

headline: More Iranians With British Links Held in Iran
abstract: Iran has arrested two Iranians with British connections in recent months and there are fears for a third, as Tehran and London bicker over a $400 million payment.

headline: E.U. Reaches Deal on Migration at Summit, but Details Sketchy
abstract: After talks in Brussels that lasted all night, leaders agreed in principle, at least, on how to shore up their external borders and create screening centers for migrants.

headline: Pope Accepts Resignation of Chilean Bishop Tied to Abuse Scandal
abstract: Victims expressed hope that the decision would open a new era in which the church hierarchy is held accountable for covering up or ignoring sexual abuse.

headline: Italy’s New Populist and Anti-Establishment Government Is Sworn In
abstract: The coalition of the Five Star Movement and the anti-immigrant League has European leaders worried about the alliance’s anti-euro tendencies and threats to crack down on migration.

headline: A Pope Given to Apologies Has Nothing for Indigenous Canada
abstract: Indigenous people are asking why Pope Francis will not be apologizing anytime soon for abuses at Catholic-run boarding schools in Canada.

headline: As Gaza Teeters on Precipice, a Hamas Leader Speaks Out
abstract: Yehya Sinwar, leader of the militant group in Gaza, is preparing for what could be the climax of weeks of protests at the fence separating the Gaza Strip from Israel.

headline: Chinese Social Media Site Reverses Gay Content Ban After Uproar
abstract: Sina Weibo vowed to scale back a “cleanup” campaign, but some gay rights advocates demanded an apology.

headline: Turkey Hands Life Sentences to 104 People Over Coup Attempt
abstract: Two crucial witnesses turned against fellow defendants and revealed details of the failed effort to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in 2016.

headline: Ties With Israel Sour as Erdogan Seizes Gaza Issue Before Election
abstract: With a rally, harsh words and a recall of ambassadors, Turkey’s president hopes to position himself as a champion of the Palestinians and leader of the Muslim world.

headline: Sermons and Shouted Insults: How Erdogan Keeps Turkey Spellbound
abstract: The Turkish president treats his country to up to three speeches a day, broadcast live on multiple channels, in a divisive style fit for an era of strongmen.

headline: How Trump’s Mixed Signals Complicate America’s Role in the World
abstract: President Trump’s inconsistent responses to Iran and North Korea risk conveying a very different message to the world than the one he may wish to send.

headline: Italian President’s Loyalty to the Euro Creates Chaos
abstract: President Sergio Mattarella enraged populists, who called for his impeachment, by rejecting a cabinet minister he feared would lead Italy out of the eurozone.

headline: The Personal Wake-Up Call to Prayers, a Ramadan Tradition, Is Endangered
abstract: The town criers that crisscross neighborhoods, waking up Muslims for dawn prayers, have met their greatest enemy yet: the modern-day cellphone alarm.

headline: Pakistan’s Taliban Names New Leader After U.S. Drone Strike
abstract: The new Taliban leader is known for running a brutal extortion racket and promoting violence against health workers across Pakistan.

headline: Deadly Tensions Rise as India’s Water Supply Runs Dangerously Low
abstract: Some 600 million Indians, about half the population, face high to extreme water scarcity conditions, with about 200,000 dying every year from inadequate access to safe water, says a government report.

headline: Once Hated by U.S. and Tied to Iran, Is Sadr Now ‘Face of Reform’ in Iraq?
abstract: Moktada al-Sadr, the upset winner of Iraq’s election, has undergone a reinvention, from a militant Shiite to an anticorruption champion whose “Iraq First” message appeals across religious divides.

headline: Pakistan Interior Minister, Champion of Minorities, Is Shot
abstract: The apparent assassination attempt came as Pakistan readies for elections. The interior minister is seen as a supporter of religious minorities.

headline: Weapons Watchdog Corrects Estimate of Nerve Agent Used in U.K. Attack
abstract: Fifty to 100 milligrams — not grams — of nerve agent were used in the March 4 poisoning of Sergei Skripal in Salisbury, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said.

headline: Large Dose of Poison Used in Attack on Ex-Spy in Britain
abstract: Roughly 50 to 100 grams of nerve agent was used in an attack on Sergei V. Skripal, a former Russian double agent, said the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons.

headline: In Israel, Building a Lacrosse League From Scratch
abstract: Eight years ago, lacrosse was a sport largely unknown in Israel. Now, thanks to an American-born entrepreneur, the country is about to host a world championship.

headline: How Facebook and Google Could Benefit From the G.D.P.R., Europe’s New Privacy Law
abstract: Facebook and Google are dealing with a privacy backlash and new European rules on data collection. The rules, though, may not be as damaging to the companies as they appear.

headline: Former Uber Engineer’s Lawsuit Claims Sexual Harassment
abstract: As Uber works to remake its tarnished image, the company is still dealing with the fallout from its past misdeeds.

headline: Emergency Braking Was Disabled When Self-Driving Uber Killed Woman, Report Says
abstract: A computer system failure and an inattentive safety driver kept the vehicle from stopping before killing a woman in Arizona in March, the National Transportation Safety Board said.

headline: Instagram Allows Longer Videos in Challenge to YouTube
abstract: The social media service said a new video hub called IGTV would allow users to post videos up to an hour in length.

headline: Uber Finds Profits in Leaving Tough Overseas Markets
abstract: The ride-hailing company also announced that it was closing its driverless car testing operations in Arizona after a deadly crash.

headline: McDonald’s to Switch to Paper Straws in Britain as Country Turns Against Plastic
abstract: The drive to reduce the use of plastics has gathered pace in Britain, winning the support of the government, the Church of England and even the queen.

headline: China’s ZTE, Saved by U.S., Has a Checkered Past and Shaky Future
abstract: As the telecom company expanded internationally, it was trailed by corruption accusations. Then it got in trouble with Washington over its Iran business.

headline: He Fled a Prison in Iceland. Now It’s Good to Be Back.
abstract: Held for questioning in a $2 million theft of Bitcoin-mining computers, Sindri Stefansson soon escaped a facility with individual rooms that have flat-screen TVs. An international manhunt ensued.

headline: China Conducts War Games, and Taiwan Is the Target
abstract: The live-fire drills in the Taiwan Strait come as China and the United States are at odds over the self-governing island, which Beijing considers its territory.

headline: Does Praise for China Make Group a ‘Foreign Agent’? Republicans Say It Might
abstract: The Natural Resources Defense Council is under fire for praising China’s cleanup efforts while challenging the Trump administration’s environmental policies.

headline: Malaysia Sidelines Officials Accused of Ignoring Graft
abstract: The country’s new government suspended officials accused of covering up a large-scale corruption scandal after the defeat of the governing coalition in an election last week.

headline: As Search for Thai Boys Lost in Cave Hits Day 5, a Nation Holds Its Breath
abstract: A dozen boys and their soccer coach, trapped in a flooded cave complex since Saturday, are the focus of a huge rescue operation and the hopes of a watching country.

headline: Malaysia Seizes Najib’s Trove of 350 Containers of Cash, Handbags and Jewelry
abstract: Raids on the former prime minister’s residences netted 72 suitcases of cash, jewels and other valuables, as well as 284 boxes of handbags, the police said.

headline: Vietnamese Protest an Opening for Chinese Territorial Interests
abstract: Already upset over Chinese claims in the region, demonstrators were protesting economic zones that would allow long leases to foreigners. At least 100 were arrested.

headline: U.S. Protester Held in Vietnam Confesses on State Television
abstract: Will Nguyen of Houston was grabbed and beaten by the police this month at an anti-China protest in Ho Chi Minh City.

headline: Judge Advances Case Against Reuters Journalists Jailed in Myanmar
abstract: They uncovered a military massacre of Rohingya Muslims. The killers they exposed were just sentenced to 10 years; the reporters may face up to 14.

headline: Paris Knife Attacker, Born in Chechnya, Was on Terrorism Watch List
abstract: As the parents of the suspect, Khamzat Azimov, 20, were being questioned by the police, opposition politicians called for a crackdown on those on the list, which has 20,000 names.

headline: Emmanuel Macron’s Bromance With Trump Takes Its Toll at Home
abstract: The French president’s warm embrace of President Trump, replete with hand holding, hugs and dandruff dusting, has opened him to public criticism.

headline: Stranded French Commuters Could Test Macron’s Reform Agenda
abstract: In its second day, a rail strike could threaten the French president’s efforts to end lifelong job security or the rail union’s standing.

headline: Paris Trial Shows Faltering Evolution of a Jihadist Cell
abstract: The five defendants once made the town of Lunel famous for sending jihadists to Syria. But their trial shows them to be lost and lured into radicalism.

headline: $21 Million in Assets Seized in South African Corruption Inquiry
abstract: The assets belong to the Guptas, three brothers who built a business empire through their ties to former President Jacob Zuma, his family and political allies.

headline: As Scandal-Tarred Abe Meets Trump, ‘the Situation Is Getting Dangerous’
abstract: Japan’s leader is consumed by scandals just as he meets President Trump to discuss North Korea and contentious trade issues.

headline: Trump’s Talk of U.S. Troop Cuts Unnerves South Korea and Japan
abstract: As President Trump weighs drawing down forces in the South, longtime Asian allies are unsettled by the prospect of giving up American protection.

headline: Japan Moves to Ease Aging Drivers Out of Their Cars
abstract: In graying Japan, concern that drivers with dementia are causing accidents has prompted the authorities to urge older people to surrender their licenses.

headline: Nixon Did It. Why Not Trump? Crib Notes for a Presidential Summit
abstract: President Nixon jotted down a few notes before his historic meeting with Mao Zedong in 1972. What should President Trump remember when he meets the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un?

headline: Trump-Kim Summit Creates New Anxieties for Asian Allies
abstract: President Trump’s concessions to North Korea exacerbated fears about America’s commitment and security guarantees. Even the Pentagon seemed confused.

headline: Trump’s On-Again, Off-Again Summit Style Unnerves Asian Allies
abstract: The zigzagging, apparently done without consulting regional allies, has aggravated questions about whether America’s partners can rely on Washington.

headline: Kim Jong-un Returns to China, This Time With Leverage
abstract: As the United States and China drift into a trade war, Mr. Kim, a week after meeting President Trump, will have the chance to play one power against the other.

headline: Korean Accord Draws Praise, and Caution, From North’s Neighbors
abstract: China, Japan and Russia, which were not part of the summit meeting, acknowledged that most of the hard work still lay ahead.

headline: Kim’s Second Surprise Visit to China Heightens Diplomatic Drama
abstract: It is without modern precedent for a leader to come to China on back-to-back visits. China is trying to keep up with a flurry of diplomatic moves.

headline: China Moves to Steady Ties With North Korea Before Trump-Kim Meeting
abstract: China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, was just in Pyongyang meeting with Kim Jong-un and trying patch up relations with North Korea after years of frosty ties.

headline: Before Kim Meets Trump, China Gets Jittery About North Korea’s Intentions
abstract: Pyongyang has depended on but also resented Beijing. Now, China appears to fear that the North may seek to counterbalance its influence by embracing America.

headline: Claiming ‘Parallel State’ Cabal, Romania’s Leaders Target Anti-Corruption Prosecutor
abstract: The governing party has worked for more than a year to reshape a judicial system that has aggressively indicted ministers, senators and others. It warns of a “deep state” that could target anyone.

headline: Thousands of Hungarians Protest Against Newly Elected Leader
abstract: The demonstrations reflect the deep divisions in this Central European country that has been at forefront of a regional drift away from liberal Western values.

headline: Soros Foundations Leaving Hungary Under Government Pressure
abstract: The Open Society Foundations said work had become untenable in Hungary, where Prime Minister Viktor Orban has stifled dissent and demonized the group’s founder.

headline: Secure in Hungary, Orban Readies for Battle with Brussels
abstract: After a commanding re-election victory, Prime Minister Viktor Orban wants to spread his anti-migration crusade across the entire European Union.

headline: Orban Campaigns on Fear, With Hungary’s Democracy at Stake
abstract: Viktor Orban’s campaign for another term as Hungary’s prime minister has been dominated by false news stories, dirty tricks and perceived enemies all around.

headline: Planning Trump-Kim Meeting: Who Sits Where, What Will They Eat and Who Pays?
abstract: The June 12 summit meeting between President Trump and Kim Jong-un requires figuring out countless details, all of which could be ignored last minute by two leaders known for changing their minds.

headline: Hopes for New Era of Malaysian Free Speech Are High, but Pending
abstract: Malaysia’s new government pledged to end harsh laws restricting expression, but activists and journalists who have faced criminal charges remain wary.

headline: Indonesia Ferry Toll Soars, With 192 Believed Dead
abstract: Passengers’ relatives criticized the government’s poor enforcement of safety standards, as officials said the boat had only been designed to carry about 40 people.

headline: Hong Kong Activist Edward Leung Given 6 Years for Police Clash
abstract: Edward Leung, who agreed with a mainland official’s label of “radical separatist,” was convicted of rioting during 2016 protests in support of street vendors.

headline: Baby in China Is Born to Surrogate 4 Years After His Parents’ Deaths
abstract: After a long legal battle, the parents of the deceased couple sued for the release of embryos conceived in vitro, and turned to a surrogacy agency in Laos.

headline: When North Met South: A Short History of Inter-Korean Summits
abstract: Two previous meetings between leaders of the Koreas paved the way for the talks Friday between Kim Jong-un and Moon Jae-in.

headline: Insurgent Attack Kills at Least 19 in Myanmar Town on Chinese Border
abstract: Officials said more than a dozen civilians died in the attack. An ethnic militia claimed responsibility.

headline: A Libyan Strongman Looks to Washington, but a Health Crisis Looms
abstract: Gen. Khalifa Hifter, who controls most of eastern Libya, is trying to woo the Trump administration as he aims to expand power. But his illness puts all that in jeopardy.

headline: Chinese Tech Giant on Brink of Collapse in New U.S. Cold War
abstract: The electronics firm ZTE has found success in the American market like few other Chinese technology brands have. Now it is fighting for its life.

headline: Alibaba’s Profit Slips as It Spends to Expand Its Empire
abstract: The Chinese e-commerce giant is spending heavily to become a full-service tech company like Google. But expanding into new ventures isn’t cheap.

headline: It Built an Empire of GIFs, Buzzy News and Jokes. China Isn’t Amused.
abstract: Bytedance, founded six years ago, is now one of the world’s most valuable tech start-ups. But it keeps finding ways to displease Chinese censors.

headline: Cardinal George Pell’s Hometown Breaks Its Silence About Grim Past of Sexual Abuse
abstract: Ballarat, once the center of Australia’s gold rush, is learning to talk about a dreadful history: decades of sexual abuse of children by Catholic priests.

headline: Australia Shudders Amid Talk of a Chinese Military Base in Its Backyard
abstract: A report that China approached Vanuatu about establishing a military presence in the island nation has raised alarm bells in the region.

headline: The Truth About Mass Shootings in Australia: The Father Usually Did It
abstract: Gun deaths are exceptionally rare in Australia, but those that do occur are often suicides. Mass shootings usually involve family members.

headline: Armenia’s Opposition, Blocked in Parliament, Raises Pressure in the Streets
abstract: Protesters heeded the calls of Nikol Pashinyan for a nationwide strike, hoping to force lawmakers into electing him as interim prime minister.

headline: As Europe’s Liberal Order Splinters, Trump Wields an Ax
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany struggled Monday to hold her coalition together. President Trump seemed to take glee in his ally’s troubles.

headline: After Viktor Orban’s Victory, Hungary’s Judges Start to Tumble
